stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

 

A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether a certain foot ointment is effective in curing athlete’s foot (a fungal infection that usually begins between a person’s toes). Two designs are proposed.

Proposal A Proposal B
Randomly select 150 people from the population of people who have athlete’s foot to use the foot ointment each day. Observe the number of people cured after one month. Obtain 150 volunteers from the population of people with athlete’s foot. Randomly assign 50 people to a group to use the foot ointment each day and 100 people to a group to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after one month.

(a) If the researcher were to choose Proposal A, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

(b) The researcher is considering using an alternate design: a matched-pairs design. Explain a benefit that a matched-pairs design would bring to the investigation and identify a characteristic that can be used to group the 150 people into pairs.

The researcher conducted the study using the design described in Proposal B. The results of the study are shown in the following bar graph.

(c) Suppose one person is randomly selected from each group (Foot Ointment and Placebo) in the study. A student claims that the likelihood of selecting a person cured of athlete’s foot is greater for the Placebo group than for the Foot Ointment group because the total number of people cured in the study is greater for the Placebo group than for the Foot Ointment group. Explain the error in the student’s claim.

The researcher will use the sample data to complete a hypothesis test to investigate the following research question.

Is there a difference between use of the foot ointment and use of the placebo in the curing of athlete’s foot?

Let pF be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured of athlete’s foot using the foot ointment and pP be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured of athlete’s foot using a placebo. The hypotheses of the test used by the researcher are as follows.

(d) Describe, in the context of the study, the consequence of making a Type I error for the test.

The conditions for inference have been met. A 90% confidence interval to estimate pF−pP is (0.25,0.47).

(e) Based on the confidence interval, how should the researcher answer the research question? Explain your answer.
